timeline.message:
SOAP Add-on Updates

- Add node names in the sites tree via
 a variant script.
- Fix a bug where some classes were not
 being loaded correctly with Java 9+.

Signed-off-by: ricekot <ricekot@gmail.com>

timeline.bodyText: I'd suggest SOAP_support.js or even soap_support.js
timeline.author: kingthorin

replies.bodyText: Okay. I went with Soap Support.js for consistency, because the GraphQL script is called GraphQL Support.js...
replies.author: ricekot

replies.bodyText: Oh okay, stick with it then.
replies.author: kingthorin

timeline.bodyText: @thc202 @psiinon do we need to think of a more generic way to do this? In a few Java revisions nashorn won't be available and we might be dependent on graalvm or something else. Should the script extension have a way to state engines for languages? (Something like getEngineForLanguage("javascript") )
timeline.author: kingthorin

replies.bodyText:
It's more reliable to use a specific engine as there are no guarantees that the other engines will support what the script is doing (while GraalVM JavaScript provides compatibility with Nashorn it might not work always).
(Latest Java version no longer include Nashorn.)
replies.author: thc202

timeline.bodyText: Should there be some sort of logged message here. Would it be better or safer to return empty string vs. null?
timeline.author: kingthorin

replies.bodyText: Good question. We could return an empty string too, but in case that is not checked by the caller it could result in an empty site node. Still, it will certainly be safer to use an empty string. Is there a middle ground ;)?
replies.author: ricekot

replies.bodyText:
If an empty name is not a valid name, then empty is better, but what matters most is that the behaviour is documented.
Re the exception being logged, I guess it could be logged as warn if that's not expected to happen frequently, otherwise debug.
replies.author: thc202
